instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with heavy liquid damage from being left out in the rain but surprisingly the board has very little corrosion.

minor corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> area. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> and a few capacitors but no changes. No 5v on charger

On pins 2 and 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> I get .200V  Checked all big coils and no shorts. First board we received without the amp meter at least coming on

What should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
So USB-C meter doesn't show anything, nor 5V at least?
In such case, check diode mode to ground at CC1/2 pins of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

Remove USB-C connector from the shell and clean the pins.
